questions.text: A 33-year-old man is evaluated by paramedics after being found unconscious outside of his home. He has no palpable pulses. Physical examination shows erythematous marks in a fern-leaf pattern on his lower extremities. An ECG shows ventricular fibrillation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The fern-leaf pattern seen on this patient's lower extremities is also referred to as a Lichtenberg figure, which is pathognomonic of a lightning strike. In about 30% of cases, a lightning strike is fatal; the most common cause of death is cardiac arrest due to a fatal arrhythmia, such as ventricular fibrillation or asystole. Superficial burns and metallization of the skin may also occur after a lightning strike injury.
Image Description:

Faint erythematous cutaneous markings in a fern leaf pattern (Lichtenberg figures; example indicated by arrow) are visible on the lower left leg.

Lichtenberg figures are pathognomonic of lightning injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Cholesterol emboli, as well as other vascular diseases that cause slower blood flow due to obstruction of blood vessels (e.g., vasculitis, atherosclerosis), can lead to livedo reticularis. However, cholesterol emboli are unlikely to lead to ventricular fibrillation and have a different appearance than the fern-leaf pattern seen here.

C) INCORRECT:

Severe hypothermia (< 82°F) can lead to pulselessness or ventricular fibrillation. However, the usual skin finding with hypothermia is livor mortis, rather than the fern-leaf pattern seen here.
Image Description:

Photograph of a deceased patient

Purple discoloration of the skin is visible in the dependent parts of the body.

This is the typical appearance of livor mortis. The intensity of the discoloration and color depends on the cause of death.

D) INCORRECT:

Opioid overdose should always be considered when a person is found unconscious without a known history of present illness or past medical history. Although opioid overdose can result in cardiac abnormalities, the associated skin findings do not appear in a fern-leaf pattern.

E) INCORRECT:

Infective endocarditis can cause arrhythmias if a perivalvular abscess forms. Skin findings associated with infective endocarditis include Janeway lesions, splinter hemorrhages, and Osler nodes. However, these skin findings do not have the fern-leaf pattern seen in this patient. Furthermore, severe constitutional symptoms (e.g., high fever, malaise) and progression over at least days would be expected with infective endocarditis.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous macules are visible on the thenar eminence and the base of the thumb.

These Janeway lesions are typically caused by septic microembolisms secondary to infective endocarditis.
questions.hint: The fern-leaf pattern on the patient's lower extremities is caused by local hyperemia.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man who is on active duty in the US Navy is brought to a military hospital because of a 1-hour history of back pain, inability to urinate, progressive leg weakness, and a burning and prickling sensation in the lower limbs. He is a military diver in training. Four hours before the onset of symptoms, he had taken part in a 3-hour scuba diving exercise to a depth of 30 m (98.4 ft). The dive was uneventful until the patient encountered problems with mask clearing, which led to a rapid ascent. About 1 hour after surfacing, the patient began to feel exceptionally tired and started having headaches. He appears somnolent. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a mottling, reticular skin rash. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the left leg and 4/5 in the right leg. Sensation to vibration and light touch is decreased over the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In a patient with DCS, hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) is the most appropriate treatment and should be initiated as soon as possible. In a high-pressure environment (e.g., during scuba diving), a large amount of gas (primarily nitrogen) is dissolved in blood and tissue fluid. With a sudden subsequent decrease in pressure (e.g., during rapid ascent), air bubbles form because the gas is no longer dissolved (Henry's law) and they begin to expand (Boyle's law). These bubbles cause local tissue damage and are primarily responsible for the multisystem manifestations of DCS, which can also include chest pain, dyspnea, myalgia, arthralgia, pruritus, painful lymphadenopathy, and lymphedema. In severe cases, air embolization can also occur. In HBOT, the patient is placed in a high-pressure chamber to decrease the number and volume of any air bubbles that have already formed, and the chamber pressure is then decreased to atmospheric pressure at a slow rate to prevent the formation of new bubbles. While in the chamber, the patient receives 100% oxygen, which creates a gradient for the diffusion of nitrogen out of the body via the lungs.

Patients who do not fully respond to therapy may require multiple sessions until complete resolution or until there is no further improvement. If an HBOT facility is not readily available, the patient should receive 100% oxygen until the patient can be moved to such a facility. Prophylaxis against deep vein thrombosis (for those with lower extremity paralysis) and adequate hydration are also recommended as adjunctive therapy in DCS.

B) INCORRECT:

Urgent lumbar decompression surgery is required to treat acute and severe spinal canal stenosis (e.g., due to trauma or disk herniation), which can similarly manifest with paresis, sensory deficits, and urinary incontinence. This patient has DCS, which requires a different treatment.

C) INCORRECT:

In the Trendelenburg position, the outflow tracts of the right ventricle (RV) and left ventricle (LV) are at a lower level than the cavities of these ventricles. This position is used to prevent obstructive shock from large venous air emboli because it allows air to accumulate near the RV wall instead of blocking the RV outflow tract. The position can also decrease the risk of arterial air emboli reaching the cerebral circulation. Although patients with severe DCS can develop venous and arterial air emboli, cerebral edema due to localized tissue damage is a much more common complication of DCS. The Trendelenburg position increases cerebral perfusion and can worsen cerebral edema and is, therefore, no longer recommended for DCS.

D) INCORRECT:

Induced hypothermia (therapeutic hypothermia) is used following ischemic stroke and return of spontaneous circulation after cardiac arrest. It is not currently used to treat decompression sickness.

E) INCORRECT:

Thrombolytic therapy is used to treat thromboembolic stroke, which occurs acutely and, when affecting the anterior cerebral artery or anterior spinal artery, can manifest with some of the features seen here (e.g., paresis and paresthesias in a lower extremity, urinary incontinence). This patient with DCS and lower extremity paralysis requires thromboprophylaxis but not thrombolytic therapy.

F) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids (e.g., dexamethasone), which reduce edema, are used to treat traumatic spinal cord injury. They are not currently recommended in the management of decompression sickness.
questions.hint: This patient has decompression sickness (DCS), which typically occurs within 24 hours after scuba diving and can affect the spinal cord (e.g., back pain, paresis and paresthesias of the lower extremities, bladder dysfunction), brain (e.g., headache, altered mental status), and skin (e.g., cutis marmorata).

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to a mountain base camp at 4000 m (13,100 ft) above sea level because he has had a 2-hour history of confusion, difficulties walking, and decreased responsiveness. He has been participating in a 5-day hiking trip in which the group has ascended 1500 m (4900 ft) from the base camp in 2 days. This morning, the third day of the trip, the patient was found in his tent unable to respond to simple questions and having wet himself. The night before, he reported headaches, dizziness, and nausea. He appears lethargic. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 89%. Neurological examination shows slurred speech and an ataxic gait. Kernig sign is absent. Further diagnostic studies cannot be performed due to limited medical equipment. The most appropriate initial step in management is the administration of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine is used in the prevention and treatment of high altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE), a complication of AMS. While the severe hypoxemia in HAPE may lead to concomitant HACE, this patient shows no signs and symptoms of HAPE, such as cough, shortness of breath, cyanosis, tachypnea, tachycardia, and crackles or wheezing on pulmonary auscultation.

B) INCORRECT:

Haloperidol is used in the treatment of acute psychosis. While some of this patient's symptoms are also seen in acute psychosis (confusion, decreased responsiveness, slurred speech), loss of bladder control, headaches, dizziness, nausea, and ataxia are not expected. Moreover, typical symptoms of acute psychosis, such as hallucinations and delusions, are not present. Finally, this patient has no reported history of mental illness that could lead to acute psychosis (e.g., schizophrenia, bipolar disorder).

C) INCORRECT:

Mannitol is used in the treatment of cerebral edema. While this drug can be used to lower intracranial pressure in severe cases of HACE, it is not the initial treatment of choice.

D) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide accelerates acclimatization to high altitude via multiple mechanisms (e.g., increased renal excretion of bicarbonate, increased ventilation and oxygenation) and is, therefore, used in the prevention and treatment of AMS. Acetazolamide is not, however, effective in the treatment of HACE.

E) CORRECT:

Dexamethasone is a rescue medication for HACE that may significantly improve the patient's condition, and it should be administered as soon as this complication is suspected. However, dexamethasone does not replace the need for immediate descent to a lower altitude, which is the definitive treatment. Oxygen supplementation and portable hyperbaric therapy are further lifesaving measures if immediate evacuation is not possible. The most effective preventive measure for AMS and HACE is a slow ascent.
questions.hint: Headaches, dizziness, and nausea while at an altitude over 2500 m (8000 ft) above sea level suggests acute mountain sickness (AMS). Altered consciousness, ataxia, and urinary incontinence are consistent with high-altitude cerebral edema (HACE), a life-threatening complication of AMS.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of hearing loss and pain in her left ear. The symptoms appeared suddenly while she was on a flight back from a business trip to New Mexico. She has had mild nasal congestion and rhinorrhea for the past 3 days. She has no other history of serious illness and takes no medications. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal examination shows mildly inflamed turbinates and purulent discharge. There is no pain to palpation over the nasal sinuses. Cervical lymph nodes are not palpable. On otoscopic examination, there is bleeding into the left tympanic cavity; the left tympanic membrane is intact. The right ear shows no abnormalities. Rinne test is negative in the left ear and positive in the right ear. Weber test lateralizes to the left. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the head is performed in patients with head trauma but is rarely used in middle ear barotrauma, which is diagnosed based on history of a potentially inciting event (e.g., flying, diving) and examination findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Myringotomy may be considered for the treatment of ear barotrauma, as it allows for temporary pressure equalization and fluid drainage from the middle ear. However, the tympanic incision usually heals before the ear barotrauma has fully resolved. This makes the use of myringotomy controversial and it is not routinely recommended. Another step is more appropriate for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral amoxicillin can be used to treat acute otitis media, which commonly manifests with unilateral ear pain and conductive hearing loss, and bacterial rhinosinusitis, which can manifest with unilateral facial pain and purulent nasal discharge. This patient has no otoscopic signs of otitis media (e.g., bulging tympanic membrane, loss of light reflex) or other characteristic findings of bacterial rhinosinusitis (e.g., fever, pressure pain over the sinuses). In middle ear barotrauma, antibiotics are only used if the tympanic membrane is ruptured.

D) CORRECT:

Middle ear barotrauma most commonly occurs during flights or while diving in patients with nasal congestion due to the inability of the Eustachian tube to equalize the pressure between the middle ear and the external environment. The excess pressure can result in injury to the structures of the middle ear. Most cases of middle ear barotrauma and subsequent lesions (e.g., tympanic edema, hemorrhage, and rupture) are self-limited with complete hearing recovery and are managed conservatively. Analgesics, such as oral ibuprofen, can be used for pain management.

E) INCORRECT:

Tympanoplasty is a second-line option for the management of tympanic membrane perforation, which can develop as a complication of ear barotrauma. This patient's otoscopic examination shows an intact tympanic membrane.
questions.hint: Sudden-onset unilateral conductive hearing loss, otalgia, and hematotympanum during a flight suggest middle ear barotrauma.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man is planning a high-altitude skiing trip to a location that has a base altitude of 9600 feet. He is worried because he developed high-altitude pulmonary edema during his last trip to the same ski resort.
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers (e.g., metoprolol) are not used to treat or prevent high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE). Beta-agonists (e.g., salmeterol) have been studied for their potential role in preventing HAPE by upregulating sodium-dependent resorption of alveolar fluid, but their use is currently not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide is used to prevent acute mountain sickness (AMS) and high-altitude cerebral edema. It does accelerate acclimatization and may provide some benefit in the prevention of HAPE, but it is not first-line therapy for secondary prevention of HAPE.

C) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) are used for the symptomatic treatment of mild acute mountain sickness but cannot prevent or treat high-altitude pulmonary edema.

D) CORRECT:

The pathophysiology of high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE) is believed to be related to acute pulmonary arterial hypertension secondary to extreme hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction. The surmised primary mechanism is stress failure of the pulmonary capillaries and leakage of edema fluid into the alveolar spaces. Decreased alveolar fluid clearance is a possible secondary mechanism.

Nifedipine has been shown to blunt the hypoxic rise in pulmonary arterial pressure and reduce the rate of recurrent HAPE in people with a history of this disorder. Nifedipine is also a first-line treatment for HAPE. Tadalafil (a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor) also has been shown to prevent HAPE by lowering pulmonary arterial pressure. Dexamethasone was shown to be effective for secondary prevention of HAPE in a single small trial.

Key learning point: Nifedipine has been shown to be effective for secondary prevention of high-altitude pulmonary edema.

E) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers (e.g., carvedilol) are not used to treat or prevent high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE). Beta-agonists (e.g., salmeterol) have been studied for their potential role in preventing HAPE by upregulating sodium-dependent resorption of alveolar fluid, but their use is currently not recommended.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents to an urgent care clinic to discuss an episode of confusion while SCUBA diving. According to the patient’s girlfriend, he did well on their first day of diving, when they descended to a depth of approximately 30 meters. On the second day, they dove to examine a wreck at a depth of 60 meters. When the man’s girlfriend signaled to start the surfacing process, he ignored her and began diving deeper, despite having relatively little oxygen left in his tank. She was eventually able to persuade him to ascend with her. Immediately afterward, he felt slightly confused, but his mental status rapidly returned to baseline.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s ephemeral confusion?

choices.text: Air embolism to the frontal cortex

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

At depths > 30 meters, breathing compressed air that is 79% nitrogen can increase nitrogen solubility into tissues, including the brain. The high partial pressure of nitrogen in the brain can cause nitrogen narcosis: an anesthetic-like effect leading to dangerous confusion and poor judgment. Using a helium-oxygen mixture in the tank can reduce this risk.

Key learning point: A diver who experiences acute onset of poor judgment, euphoria, and/or confusion is likely to be suffering from nitrogen narcosis.

B) INCORRECT:

In decompression sickness, the supersaturated tissues can form nitrogen gas bubbles when pressure decreases rapidly during rapid resurfacing. The air bubbles can cause both end-organ damage and limb pain (“the bends”). Divers can avoid decompression sickness by adhering to diving protocols and by ascending from a dive gradually. If decompression sickness is mild, recompression by descending in the water may help; if it is severe, hyperbaric therapy may be needed.

C) INCORRECT:

Rebreathing syndrome is not a consequence of diving; it refers to hypoxemia caused when an individual rebreathes into a paper bag in an attempt to treat hyperventilation.

D) INCORRECT:

Shallow-water blackout occurs when a person attempts to dive in shallow water by holding the breath. The diver can decrease his or her partial pressure of carbon dioxide by hyperventilating and subsequently blunting the hypercapnic drive to breathe. If the partial pressure of oxygen then falls more quickly than the partial pressure of carbon dioxide rises, the diver can become severely hypoxemic and lose consciousness.

E) INCORRECT:

Barotrauma usually occurs in people who perform free dives; who rapidly ascend; or who have underlying obstructive lung disease, pulmonary blebs, or cysts. The increased pressure in the airways can lead to extravasation of air along the bronchial tree, which may cause air embolism.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man who is hiking at an altitude of 2600 meters develops headache and nausea. He has no medical problems and does not take any medications. He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative.
On physical examination, he is fully alert and oriented. He appears to be uncomfortable but in no acute distress. His temperature is 36.4°C, his blood pressure is 115/80 mm Hg, his heart rate is 85 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 94% while he breathes ambient air. He has mild peripheral and facial edema. His respiratory examination is normal. There are no neurological deficits. He walks with a steady gait.
In addition to avoiding any further ascent, which one of the following medications should this patient receive?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids, such as dexamethasone, are used for their antiinflammatory effects in vasogenic brain edema and are therefore used for HACE, sometimes in conjunction with acetazolamide. Dexamethasone is also beneficial in the treatment of AMS but is not considered first-line therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Tadalafil, a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor, has been studied for HAPE prevention and has been used for HAPE treatment in case reports, but it does not have a role in treatment of mild AMS.

C) INCORRECT:

Diuretics, such as furosemide, are claimed to prevent AMS and HAPE, but this therapy is controversial and is not appropriate for AMS.

D) INCORRECT:

Calcium-channel blockers (CCBs), such as nifedipine, are used in both the prevention and treatment of HAPE but are not effective in AMS. A CCB has pulmonary vasodilating effects and often improves the saturation level of oxygen in hemoglobin within a few minutes.

E) CORRECT:

Ascent to altitudes above 2400 meters is associated with a reduced partial pressure of oxygen that can trigger several physiological reflexes that affect cerebral blood flow. These include hypoxic cerebral vasodilatation, hypocapnic cerebral vasoconstriction, the hypoxic ventilator response, and the hypercapnic ventilator response.

Faster ascents and shorter acclimatization increase the risk for altitude-associated illness, such as acute mountain sickness (AMS) and high-altitude cerebral edema (HACE). High-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE), another altitude-associated illness, is a noncardiogenic form of pulmonary edema related to a leak in the alveolar capillary membrane. Slow ascent can help prevent altitude-associated illnesses, and pharmacologic therapies can be used in certain scenarios. Acetazolamide is the most commonly used medication to prevent AMS/HACE and is used in those with a history of AMS and in those who are ascending quickly or to very high altitudes. It acts as a respiratory stimulant and increases renal bicarbonate excretion.

AMS symptoms are nonspecific and range in severity. They generally begin in the first 48 hours after ascent above 2500 meters. The most common symptom is a throbbing frontal headache. Fluid retention is characteristic, and many patients with AMS develop oliguria. AMS is diagnosed in a patient who has headache plus at least one of the following types of symptoms: gastrointestinal (nausea, vomiting, anorexia); constitutional (weakness, dizziness, lightheadedness, fatigue); or insomnia. The main factor that distinguishes AMS from HAPE or HACE is the absence of neurologic changes, such as confusion or lethargy. AMS is generally self-limiting, with resolution of symptoms in 1 to 3 days without treatment. AMS is more likely to worsen and progress to HACE, however, if ascent is continued.

The most appropriate management of AMS includes no further ascent until symptoms resolve, descent if medication does not improve symptoms, or immediate descent if HACE is suspected. Medical therapy for AMS should focus on symptom management. A nonopioid analgesic, such as ibuprofen, is appropriate for symptomatic control of mild-to-moderate pain and headache in AMS. Ibuprofen assists in headache control through an antiinflammatory effect and a decrease in prostaglandin synthesis.

Key learning point: The most appropriate medication to treat headache in a person with acute mountain sickness is ibuprofen.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old girl seeks medical clearance for scuba diving, which she would like to do with her family on an upcoming vacation to Hawaii. She has never gone scuba diving before and is enrolled in a scuba certification class that begins next week.
Her medical history is significant for moderately well-controlled asthma, type 1 diabetes diagnosed 2 years ago and controlled with an insulin pump, febrile seizures that occurred when she was 2 years of age, and tympanostomy with removal of the tubes.
What is the most appropriate message to convey to this patient regarding her upcoming trip?

choices.text: She can dive if her FEV1 is >90% predicted for age and sex
She can dive if her parents provide informed consent and acknowledge the risk
She can dive if the tympanostomy tubes were removed at least 6 months before the planned diving
She can dive if she has had no severe hypoglycemic events for 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients who have well-controlled asthma and normal spirometry both at rest and with exercise may participate in scuba diving. If there are current symptoms, abnormal spirometry at rest, or a greater than 15% decrease in FEV1 with exercise, the patient should not be cleared to dive.

B) CORRECT:

Type 1 diabetes is generally considered a contraindication to scuba diving for adolescents. However, medical clearance is reasonable for selected adults — specifically, those with well-controlled type 1 diabetes on a stable dose of insulin who are physically fit and very experienced with glucose management (without secondary diabetic complications, recent episodes of hypoglycemia, or hypoglycemia unawareness). There are special diving safety protocols for adults with type 1 diabetes that involve allowing frequent monitoring and allowing a significant increase in blood glucose on the day of the dive. This patient, who is a novice diver with a relatively new diabetes diagnosis, is too young to be cleared for scuba diving because the risks to her could be substantial if she has difficulty complying with the complex protocol.

Febrile seizures are not a contraindication to scuba diving, but a history of any other type of seizure is a contraindication.

Patients who have well-controlled asthma and normal spirometry both at rest and with exercise may participate in scuba diving. If there are current symptoms, abnormal spirometry at rest, or a greater than 15% decrease in FEV1 with exercise, the patient should not be cleared to dive.

Children with tympanostomy tubes in place should not be routinely discouraged from swimming or shallow diving, but deep diving may be advised against. There are no clear recommendations on the waiting period after tube removal before engaging in deep diving but this activity is generally safe if the tympanic membrane has healed and the patient can equalize middle ear pressure.

Key learning point: For an adolescent who wants to go scuba diving, type 1 diabetes is a contraindication.

C) INCORRECT:

Type 1 diabetes is a generally considered a contraindication to scuba diving for adolescents. It is not appropriate to seek or offer informed consent for an activity that is absolutely contraindicated.

D) INCORRECT:

The American Academy of Otolaryngology-Head and Neck Surgery Foundation (AAO-HNSF) guidelines state that children with tympanostomy tubes in place should not be routinely discouraged from swimming or shallow diving, but deep diving may be advised against. There are no clear recommendations on the waiting period after tube removal before engaging in deep diving but this activity is generally safe if the tympanic membrane has healed and the patient can equalize middle ear pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

Type 1 diabetes is a generally considered a contraindication to scuba diving for adolescents. However, medical clearance is reasonable for selected adults — specifically, those with well-controlled type 1 diabetes on a stable dose of insulin who are physically fit and very experienced with glucose management (without secondary diabetic complications, recent episodes of hypoglycemia, or hypoglycemia unawareness).

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after experiencing a low-voltage electrical burn on his right hand, sustained while grasping a hairdryer while he was in the bathtub. His mother reports he has vomited three times since the event and has been guarding his right hand. He is otherwise healthy with no daily medications or allergies.
On examination, he has a heart rate of 95 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while breathing ambient air. He is awake but disoriented, intermittently closing his eyes and moaning. He opens his eyes when asked and withdraws his arm with placement of an intravenous line. His hair is wet, but his skin is now dry. He has a well-demarcated, erythematous lesion measuring 3 cm over the palmar aspect of his right hand. The lesion appears to be blistering. There are no circumferential or white lesions noted. He withdraws when you touch his palm; and, overall, sensation and strength appear to be intact in both hands. He has normal heart and lung sounds, and an abdominal examination is unremarkable.
An electrocardiogram shows a sinus rhythm with a normal rate, normal axis, and normal intervals.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Pack the right hand in ice

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although local wound care, including cooling of severe burns, is indicated, ice should not be used because of the risk of tissue damage from the ice itself.

B) INCORRECT:

Given that this patient is presenting with localized injury and an intact neurovascular examination, emergency surgical consultation is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Children with uncomplicated low-voltage electrical burns do not typically have foreign bodies or bony fractures and therefore do not require radiographs.

D) INCORRECT:

Intubation is not necessary for this patient at this time. Although he has altered mental status, he is protecting his own airway and breathing without distress. Indications for intubation include a Glasgow Coma Scale score ≤8 (this patient’s score is 11), rapid neurologic deterioration, progressive upper-airway edema (e.g., from inhalation injury), and respiratory failure.

E) CORRECT:

Electrical burns are common in young children because of their exploratory nature. Indoor household outlets are the most common source of electrical exposure and are classified as low-voltage because they conduct <1000 volts. Lower-acuity electrical burns can occur when children insert foreign objects or their fingers into power outlets or when they bite power cords. When water is involved, however, as in this case, the consequences of a low-voltage exposure may be more severe because water greatly reduces resistance of the skin, leading to increased conduction of the electrical current.

Typical studies after an electrical exposure include an electrocardiogram, a basic metabolic panel to check electrolyte derangements and kidney function, measurement of creatine kinase l to assess for rhabdomyolysis, and measurement of urine myoglobin to assess for renal damage related to potentially excessive production of myoglobin. Children who present with high-voltage (>1000 volts) electrical burns, wet low-voltage burns, or altered mental status after a burn are at increased risk for intracranial bleeding due to vascular damage and should therefore undergo a noncontrast CT of the brain.

Key learning point: In patients with electrical burns and altered mental status, the best next step in evaluation after obtaining an electrocardiogram is a noncontrast head CT.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman comes to the office because of ear pain, muffled hearing, tinnitus, and aural fullness for the past 2 weeks. The symptoms started during an airline flight she took while experiencing concurrent nasal congestion and cough. Otoscopic examination reveals that the tympanic membrane is in the neutral position, appears thickened with an amber hue, and is immobile. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute myringitis is characterized by an inflamed drum, decreased hearing, and, usually, scant ear drainage.

B) INCORRECT:

In acute otitis media, the tympanic membrane appears bulging and erythematous, often with a purulent effusion.

C) INCORRECT:

In chronic otitis media, the tympanic membrane appears scarred and retracted, and associated perforation or cholesteatoma may be present.

D) CORRECT:

During an upper respiratory tract infection, the mucosal linings of the eustachian tubes and nasal cavity swell, which may result in eustachian tube dysfunction and poor equilibrium between middle-ear pressure and atmospheric pressure. Barotrauma from air travel is more likely to occur in this setting and may cause middle-ear effusion, which can persist for up to a month. Symptoms of effusion include aural fullness, muffled hearing, tinnitus, and a sense of imbalance. Otalgia can accompany middle-ear effusion following barotrauma. Otoscopic examination will reveal a stiff tympanic membrane in a neutral or retracted position and an amber-colored middle-ear effusion.

Key learning point: In middle-ear effusions, the two most typical physical characteristics of the tympanic membrane are amber color and lack of mobility.

E) INCORRECT:

Hemotympanum may occur in the setting of barotrauma or basilar skull fracture but would appear as dark-red blood behind the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of hearing loss and pain in her left ear for the past 3 days. The symptoms appeared suddenly during a flight she took while experiencing concurrent nasal congestion. Vital signs are within normal limits. On otoscopic examination, there is blood in the left tympanic cavity; the left tympanic membrane is intact. The right ear shows no abnormalities. Hearing studies show conductive hearing loss of the left ear. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the head is performed in patients with head trauma but is rarely used in middle ear barotrauma, which is diagnosed based on history of a potentially inciting event (e.g., flying, diving) and examination findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Myringotomy may be considered for the treatment of ear barotrauma, as it allows for temporary pressure equalization and fluid drainage from the middle ear. However, the tympanic incision usually heals before the ear barotrauma has fully resolved. This makes the use of myringotomy controversial and it is not routinely recommended. Another step is more appropriate for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin) can be used to treat acute otitis media, which commonly manifests with unilateral ear pain and conductive hearing loss. This patient has no otoscopic signs of otitis media (e.g., bulging tympanic membrane, loss of light reflex). In middle ear barotrauma, antibiotics are only used if the tympanic membrane is ruptured.

D) CORRECT:

Middle ear barotrauma most commonly occurs during flights or while diving in patients with nasal congestion due to the inability of the Eustachian tube to equalize the pressure between the middle ear and the external environment. The excess pressure can result in injury to the structures of the middle ear. Most cases of middle ear barotrauma and subsequent lesions (e.g., tympanic edema, hemorrhage, and rupture) are self-limited with complete hearing recovery and are managed conservatively. Analgesics (e.g., NSAIDs) can be used for pain management.

E) INCORRECT:

Tympanoplasty is a second-line option for the management of tympanic membrane perforation, which can develop as a complication of ear barotrauma. This patient's otoscopic examination shows an intact tympanic membrane.
questions.hint: Sudden-onset unilateral conductive hearing loss, otalgia, and hematotympanum during a flight suggest middle ear barotrauma.

questions.text: An 18-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of ear pain, muffled hearing, tinnitus, and aural fullness. Her symptoms began during an airline flight while she had nasal congestion and cough. Otoscopic examination shows a tympanic membrane in the neutral position, with a thickened, amber appearance, and immobility. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

During an upper respiratory tract infection, the mucosal linings of the eustachian tubes and nasal cavity swell, which may result in eustachian tube dysfunction and poor equilibrium between middle-ear pressure and atmospheric pressure. Barotrauma from air travel is more likely to occur in this setting and may cause middle-ear effusion, which can persist for up to a month. Symptoms of effusion include aural fullness, muffled hearing, tinnitus, and a sense of imbalance. Otalgia can accompany middle-ear effusion following barotrauma. Otoscopic examination will reveal a stiff tympanic membrane in a neutral or retracted position and an amber-colored middle-ear effusion.

Key learning point: In middle-ear effusions, the two most typical physical characteristics of the tympanic membrane are amber color and lack of mobility.

B) INCORRECT:

In chronic otitis media, the tympanic membrane appears scarred and retracted, and associated perforation or cholesteatoma may be present.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemotympanum may occur in the setting of barotrauma or basilar skull fracture but would appear as dark-red blood behind the tympanic membrane.

D) INCORRECT:

In acute otitis media, the tympanic membrane appears bulging and erythematous, often with a purulent effusion.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute myringitis is characterized by an inflamed drum, decreased hearing, and, usually, scant ear drainage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of hearing loss and pain in her left ear. The symptoms began suddenly during a recent flight while she was experiencing nasal congestion. Vital signs are normal. Otoscopic examination reveals blood in the left tympanic cavity with an intact tympanic membrane. The right ear is normal. Hearing studies demonstrate conductive hearing loss in the left ear. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the head is performed in patients with head trauma but is rarely used in middle ear barotrauma, which is diagnosed based on history of a potentially inciting event (e.g., flying, diving) and examination findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Myringotomy may be considered for the treatment of ear barotrauma, as it allows for temporary pressure equalization and fluid drainage from the middle ear. However, the tympanic incision usually heals before the ear barotrauma has fully resolved. This makes the use of myringotomy controversial and it is not routinely recommended. Another step is more appropriate for this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Middle ear barotrauma most commonly occurs during flights or while diving in patients with nasal congestion due to the inability of the Eustachian tube to equalize the pressure between the middle ear and the external environment. The excess pressure can result in injury to the structures of the middle ear. Most cases of middle ear barotrauma and subsequent lesions (e.g., tympanic edema, hemorrhage, and rupture) are self-limited with complete hearing recovery and are managed conservatively. Analgesics (e.g., NSAIDs) can be used for pain management.

Key learning point: Middle ear barotrauma is usually self-limited and managed conservatively with symptomatic treatment, such as analgesics for pain relief.

D) INCORRECT:

Tympanoplasty is a second-line option for the management of tympanic membrane perforation, which can develop as a complication of ear barotrauma. This patient's otoscopic examination shows an intact tympanic membrane.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin) can be used to treat acute otitis media, which commonly manifests with unilateral ear pain and conductive hearing loss. This patient has no otoscopic signs of otitis media (e.g., bulging tympanic membrane, loss of light reflex). In middle ear barotrauma, antibiotics are only used if the tympanic membrane is ruptured.
questions.hint: Sudden-onset unilateral conductive hearing loss, otalgia, and hematotympanum during a flight suggest middle ear barotrauma.

questions.text: A 28-year-old recreational diver presents to the emergency department after surfacing from a 6-meter dive lasting 20 minutes. The patient reports feeling normal during the dive but developed sudden confusion and left arm weakness immediately upon reaching the surface. Physical examination shows altered mental status, left hemiparesis, and an irregular pulse. Vital signs are BP, 85/55; P, 115 irregular; R, 24; oxygen saturation, 92% on room air. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Echocardiogram to assess for patent foramen ovale
Neurological consultation for workup of seizure
CT head to rule out stroke
Chest radiograph to evaluate for pneumothorax

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While a patent foramen ovale can predispose individuals to arterial gas embolism by allowing venous bubbles to cross into arterial circulation, echocardiography is not the immediate priority. The focus should be emergency treatment of the suspected arterial gas embolism rather than investigating underlying anatomical predispositions.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's diving history and the timing of symptom onset make arterial gas embolism the most likely diagnosis. Neurological consultation would delay the time-sensitive treatment required for arterial gas embolism. In addition, this patient's presentation is not consistent with typical seizure activity.

C) INCORRECT:

While stroke is in the differential diagnosis, the temporal relationship to diving and the specific clinical presentation make arterial gas embolism more likely. Delaying treatment for imaging when arterial gas embolism is suspected can worsen outcomes, as recompression therapy is time-sensitive.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Neurological symptoms and arrhythmias immediately after surfacing strongly suggest arterial gas embolism. The most critical intervention is immediate administration of 100% oxygen and hyperbaric oxygen therapy consultation. Arterial gas embolism can occur even after brief, shallow dives and requires emergency recompression treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Although chest radiography may be useful to evaluate for pneumothorax as a complication of pulmonary barotrauma, the primary presentation is neurological rather than respiratory. The immediate priority is treating the suspected arterial gas embolism rather than investigating potential complications.

questions.text: A 32-year-old experienced scuba diver presents with chest pain and dyspnea that began during ascent from a 15-meter dive. The patient reports holding their breath during a rapid ascent due to equipment malfunction. Examination shows subcutaneous crepitus in the supraclavicular region. Vital signs are normal. Chest x-ray shows no acute abnormalities. The patient is alert and oriented with no focal neurological deficits. What is the most appropriate immediate step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Emergency thoracostomy tube placement is not indicated for this stable patient. The management approach should be conservative initially with oxygen therapy and monitoring, as many cases of pulmonary barotrauma resolve spontaneously with appropriate supportive care.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- High-flow oxygen administration with close monitoring for pneumothorax development is the most appropriate immediate step in management. Pulmonary barotrauma with subcutaneous crepitus indicates alveolar rupture; pneumothorax is the most life-threatening complication that may not be immediately visible on chest x-ray and can develop rapidly.

C) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is not the immediate priority in suspected pulmonary barotrauma. This patient's clinical presentation with subcutaneous crepitus after breath-holding during ascent is diagnostic; immediate management with oxygen and monitoring takes precedence over advanced imaging.

D) INCORRECT:

Needle decompression is indicated for tension pneumothorax with hemodynamic compromise. This patient has normal vital signs and no evidence of tension pneumothorax, making immediate decompression inappropriate without further assessment.

E) INCORRECT:

While hyperbaric oxygen therapy may be considered for certain diving-related complications, the immediate priority is stabilization with high-flow oxygen and monitoring for pneumothorax development.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department 2 hours after a recreational dive. He reports joint pain and mild numbness in his extremities. His diving computer shows a maximum depth of 25 meters with a normal ascent rate. Vital signs are normal. Neurological examination shows decreased sensation in both hands but is otherwise unremarkable. What is the most appropriate initial intervention?

choices.text: CT scan of the brain and spine

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- 100% oxygen should be administered immediately to all patients with suspected decompression sickness. This is the most important first-line treatment that can be initiated in the emergency department. The high-flow oxygen helps reduce bubble size and improves tissue oxygenation while definitive care is arranged.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids are not part of the standard first-line treatment for decompression sickness. They may be considered in specific cases of inner ear barotrauma, but immediate oxygen administration is the priority in suspected decompression sickness.

C) INCORRECT:

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy is the definitive treatment for decompression sickness but requires specialized equipment and specialist consultation.

D) INCORRECT:

Advanced imaging may be considered in patients with decompression sickness and significant neurological deficits, but the immediate priority is oxygen administration. Decompression sickness is primarily a clinical diagnosis based on diving history and symptom timing.

E) INCORRECT:

While supportive care, including cautious IV fluids, may be part of management, it is not first-line treatment for decompression sickness. The priority is addressing the underlying pathophysiology.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the emergency department 2 hours after completing an 85-foot recreational dive. She reports ascending faster than recommended due to low air supply. On examination, she has altered mental status with confusion, severe headache, and visual disturbances. Physical examination shows bilateral lower extremity weakness, sensory loss at the T10 dermatome, and urinary retention. Vital signs are BP, 150/85; P, 105; R, 18; oxygen saturation, 92% on room air. Which of the following clinical features most reliably indicates decompression sickness type II rather than type I?

choices.text: Neurological involvement with spinal cord dysfunction
Severe bilateral shoulder and knee joint pain

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Myalgia affecting multiple muscle groups is a musculoskeletal manifestation consistent with type I decompression sickness.

B) INCORRECT:

Cutaneous manifestations including mottling and pruritus can occur in both type I and type II decompression sickness. These skin findings alone do not reliably distinguish between the two types.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Neurological involvement with spinal cord dysfunction is a defining feature distinguishing decompression sickness type II from type I. Type II involves organ systems beyond muscles, joints, and skin, particularly the central nervous system, lungs, and ears. Spinal cord manifestations include weakness, paralysis, and sensory dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Subcutaneous emphysema and chest pain are more characteristic of pulmonary barotrauma than of decompression sickness. While chest pain can occur in type II decompression sickness, subcutaneous emphysema indicates alveolar rupture from barotrauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Severe joint pain in the shoulders and knees is characteristic of type I decompression sickness, which is limited to musculoskeletal structures. Joint pain alone does not distinguish type II from type I decompression sickness.

questions.text: A 42-year-old recreational diver presents with progressively worsening joint pain in both knees and shoulders that began 3 hours after completing a 35-meter dive. The patient completed appropriate decompression stops and reports no breath-holding during ascent. Physical examination shows joint tenderness without swelling, and vital signs are normal. The patient mentions planning to fly home tomorrow morning. Which factor in this patient's history most significantly influences the urgency of treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While diving to 35 meters increases the risk of decompression illness, this depth alone does not significantly alter treatment urgency because the patient has already developed symptoms. The dive profile is important for diagnosis but does not impact the immediate treatment timeline.

B) INCORRECT:

Age is a patient-related risk factor for decompression illness, but an age of 42 years does not significantly influence treatment urgency. Age-related risk factors are more relevant for prevention and risk stratification rather than acute management decisions.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- Air travel shortly after diving creates additional decompression stress due to reduced cabin pressure, which can worsen existing decompression illness and precipitate further bubble formation. This significantly increases treatment urgency, as the patient should not fly until definitively treated and cleared, making immediate hyperbaric oxygen therapy more time-sensitive.

D) INCORRECT:

Symptom onset 3 hours after surfacing is typical for decompression illness, as most cases develop within 24 hours. This timing supports the diagnosis but does not create additional urgency beyond the standard need for prompt hyperbaric oxygen therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Avoiding breath-holding during ascent reduces the risk of arterial gas embolism and is a key component of safe diving. This appropriate behavior does not influence treatment urgency.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man who is a roofer is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious by coworkers during a thunderstorm. He arrives alert but disoriented with no recall of events. Vital signs are BP, 140/85; P, 108; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F); oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals bilateral mydriasis with sluggish light response, superficial burns on his torso, and fern-like erythematous patterns across his chest and back. His hard hat shows evidence of electrical tracking, and his metal belt buckle appears melted. ECG demonstrates sinus tachycardia with nonspecific ST-T wave changes. Which finding is most specific for differentiating his injury mechanism from high-voltage electrical trauma?

choices.text: Nonspecific ST-T wave changes on ECG

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- Fern-like erythematous skin patterns are Lichtenberg figures, pathognomonic for lightning injury. These distinctive branching patterns result from local hyperemia along the path of electrical discharge.

B) INCORRECT:

Bilateral mydriasis with sluggish light response can occur in both lightning strikes and high-voltage electrical injuries due to autonomic dysfunction. This finding cannot reliably distinguish between the two mechanisms.

C) INCORRECT:

Nonspecific ST-T wave changes are common cardiac manifestations that can occur with both lightning strikes and high-voltage electrical injuries. These ECG abnormalities reflect myocardial injury or conduction disturbances.

D) INCORRECT:

Melting of metal objects (metalization) occurs in both lightning strikes and high-voltage electrical injuries when electrical current is transmitted to metallic items, causing them to heat rapidly.

E) INCORRECT:

Electrical tracking patterns on protective equipment can occur with both lightning strikes and high-voltage electrical contact.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with bilateral lower extremity flaccid paralysis and absent pulses in both legs after being found unconscious outdoors. He is now alert. Physical examination shows faint branching erythematous skin markings on his chest. Upper extremities have normal strength and pulses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While acute spinal cord injury can cause bilateral lower extremity flaccid paralysis, it does not explain this patient's branching erythematous skin markings or absent lower extremity pulses.

B) INCORRECT:

Bilateral acute limb ischemia causes absent pulses but typically manifests with severe pain, pallor, and coldness rather than flaccid paralysis. This patient's branching skin markings and selective lower extremity neurological involvement are not consistent with pure vascular occlusion.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – Keraunoparalysis is a transient flaccid paralysis with sensory loss and vascular spasm that occurs immediately after lightning strike. The legs are often more severely affected than arms, mimicking spinal cord injury. The branching erythematous patterns represent Lichtenberg figures, which are pathognomonic for lightning injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome typically manifests with ascending weakness that starts distally and progresses over minutes to weeks. The acute onset, absent pulses, and characteristic skin findings in this patient make this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypokalemic periodic paralysis typically affects proximal muscles symmetrically in both upper and lower extremities. It does not cause the selective lower extremity pattern seen in this patient or explain the vascular findings and characteristic skin markings.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man who is a maintenance worker presents after electrical contact with an unknown voltage source. He reports brief tetanic muscle contraction and has a small burn on his palm with localized numbness. Vital signs are stable, initial ECG shows normal sinus rhythm, and the patient denies systemic symptoms. Investigation reveals the source was a 240V industrial circuit. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain laboratory studies, including CBC and CPK
Observe for 6-8 hours with serial ECGs
Discharge with wound care and return precautions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Laboratory studies including CBC, CMP, CPK, and myoglobin are indicated for high-voltage injuries and/or significant symptoms. This patient's low-voltage injury with minimal localized symptoms does not require additional diagnostic testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Continuous cardiac monitoring is indicated for high-voltage injuries and/or significant symptoms. This patient has low-voltage exposure with only localized symptoms, making monitoring unnecessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Burn center transfer is considered for extensive burns or high-voltage injuries requiring specialized management. A small superficial burn from low-voltage exposure can be managed with wound care.

D) INCORRECT:

Extended observation with serial ECGs is not indicated for low-voltage electrical injuries when symptoms are minimal and localized.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Low-voltage electrical injuries with minimal and localized symptoms can be managed with discharge after local wound care and providing return precautions. No additional diagnostics or prolonged monitoring are indicated when symptoms remain minimal and localized.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is brought to the ED after police subdued him with a Taser during an arrest for disorderly conduct. He has minor skin irritation at the weapon's contact points. Vital signs are normal. Officers report the initial application was ineffective, requiring reapplication. Physical examination is otherwise unremarkable except for a small laceration on his forehead. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order comprehensive metabolic panel and cardiac enzymes
Obtain ECG and observe for several hours
Obtain CT head and cervical spine imaging
Start IV fluids and pain management

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discharge is inappropriate without determining the total duration of exposure and ensuring adequate evaluation. The reapplication of the Taser suggests prolonged exposure that warrants further assessment.

B) INCORRECT:

Comprehensive laboratory studies including cardiac enzymes are not indicated for conducted electrical weapon exposures, which typically cause minor clinical effects.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – The reapplication of the Taser suggests that the total electrical exposure likely exceeded 15 seconds. ECG and consideration of 6–8 hours of observation are indicated for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

While this patient's forehead laceration suggests possible fall-related trauma, routine imaging is not indicated based on this presentation alone.

E) INCORRECT:

Supportive care with IV fluids and pain management are unnecessary for this patient, and the immediate priority is cardiac evaluation based on the prolonged electrical exposure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after an incident at a construction site involving power lines. He is awake and oriented but reports chest discomfort and paresthesias in his right arm. Vital signs are BP, 134/78; P, 88; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F); oxygen saturation, 98% on room air. Physical examination shows circular burns on his right palm and left foot. After completing the primary survey, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain focused history of electrical exposure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cardiac enzyme levels, including troponin and creatine kinase-MB, are not recommended for screening for cardiac injury in patients with electrical injuries as their diagnostic utility is unknown in this population.

B) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is indicated for patients with ECG abnormalities to evaluate a suspected cardiac injury, but the initial ECG must be obtained first to determine if echocardiography is necessary.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- After completing the primary survey, obtaining a 12-lead ECG is the most appropriate immediate diagnostic step. ECG is the first diagnostic test to evaluate for cardiac dysrhythmias and conduction abnormalities, which are common complications of an electrical injury. The ECG findings will guide subsequent management decisions.

D) INCORRECT:

IV fluid resuscitation with a target urine output of 1–1.5 mL/kg/hour is important for electrical injuries but should be started after other diagnostic studies are completed.

E) INCORRECT:

Obtaining a focused history including voltage and type of current, associated trauma, and underlying medical conditions is an important component of initial management for electrical injuries. However, after completing the primary survey, obtaining an ECG is the immediate diagnostic priority to assess for cardiac dysrhythmias and conduction abnormalities.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with headache, nausea, and difficulty sleeping. She just traveled to a city at 1600 m elevation and reports feeling unwell since arrival. She appears fatigued with mild peripheral edema. Neurological examination shows no focal deficits or ataxia. Oxygen saturation is 89% on room air. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient does not have key diagnostic features of high-altitude cerebral edema such as altered mental status or ataxia. A different diagnosis is more likely.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient's symptoms are characteristic of acute mountain sickness. Acute mountain sickness typically develops 4–12 hours after rapid ascent to altitudes above 2000–2500 m, but symptoms can occur at lower elevations in susceptible individuals.

C) INCORRECT:

A viral syndrome does not explain this patient's mild hypoxemia or the temporal relationship between symptom onset and altitude exposure.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyponatremia can cause headache, nausea, and altered mental status, but it does not typically cause the mild hypoxemia seen in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Carbon monoxide poisoning may cause nausea, headache, and fatigue, but this patient has no known carbon monoxide exposure. Another diagnosis is more likely based on this patient's travel history.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, who is a hiker, presents to a mountain clinic 36 hours after ascending from 1800 m to 4100 m. She reports headache, nausea, and difficulty sleeping. Physical examination shows confusion, inability to perform heel-to-toe walking, and blurred vision. Oxygen saturation is 84% on room air. What is the most appropriate immediate step in management?

choices.text: Nifedipine and continuous positive airway pressure

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While dexamethasone and oxygen are important treatments for high-altitude cerebral edema, immediate descent is the most critical intervention.

B) INCORRECT:

Hyperbaric oxygen therapy can be beneficial for high-altitude cerebral edema but is not the most appropriate immediate step in management. Immediate descent remains the most critical intervention, and hyperbaric oxygen therapy should be considered as an adjunctive therapy if available.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with altered mental status and ataxia, which are key diagnostic findings of high-altitude cerebral edema (HACE). HACE is a medical emergency that requires immediate descent as the primary intervention. This should be combined with high-flow oxygen therapy titrated to a target oxygen saturation > 90%.

D) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide is appropriate for acute mountain sickness but inadequate for this patient who has neurological findings consistent with high-altitude cerebral edema. This approach would delay definitive treatment of a medical emergency.

E) INCORRECT:

Nifedipine and continuous positive airway pressure are treatments for high-altitude pulmonary edema, not cerebral edema. This patient's neurological symptoms indicate cerebral rather than pulmonary pathology.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with dyspnea and fatigue after hiking to an elevation of 4200 m 48 hours ago. She has a dry cough and reports difficulty sleeping. Physical examination shows bilateral crackles. Vital signs are P, 110; B, 125/80 mm Hg, oxygen saturation, 84% on room air. Chest x-ray shows patchy bilateral infiltrates without cardiomegaly. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While nifedipine can be used as an adjunctive therapy for high-altitude pulmonary edema as it reduces pulmonary vascular resistance, it should only be considered when immediate descent and oxygen are not feasible.

B) INCORRECT:

Corticosteroids like dexamethasone are used for high-altitude cerebral edema (HACE), not high-altitude pulmonary edema, and are not appropriate for this patient's presentation.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's rapid ascent, bilateral crackles, hypoxia, and bilateral infiltrates without cardiomegaly indicate high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE). HAPE is a medical emergency that requires immediate descent.

D) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide is primarily used to prevent and treat acute mountain sickness, not established high-altitude pulmonary edema. This patient requires immediate descent and oxygen therapy due to the severity of her condition and significant hypoxia.

E) INCORRECT:

Furosemide is a treatment for cardiogenic pulmonary edema, not high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE). HAPE is a noncardiogenic edema caused by increased pulmonary vascular permeability secondary to hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction. The absence of cardiomegaly suggests a noncardiogenic cause.

questions.text: A 32-year-old mountaineer presents 18 hours after ascending from sea level to 3400 m (11,150 feet) in one day. She reports headache, nausea, and fatigue that began 6 hours after arrival. Her climbing partner notes she has been increasingly irritable and confused over the past 2 hours. Vital signs are P, 92; BP, 125/78; R, 20; oxygen saturation, 87% on room air. She is oriented to person and place but not time. What additional finding would confirm the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: Truncal ataxia on tandem gait testing

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While peripheral edema can occur in acute mountain sickness, it is not a distinguishing feature of high-altitude cerebral edema and does not indicate cerebellar dysfunction.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary crackles are more suggestive of high-altitude pulmonary edema rather than high-altitude cerebral edema, which is characterized by neurological rather than pulmonary symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Pink frothy sputum is characteristic of high-altitude pulmonary edema rather than high-altitude cerebral edema, which primarily manifests with neurological symptoms rather than respiratory findings.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of altered mental status and ataxia is the key diagnostic finding that differentiates high-altitude cerebral edema from acute mountain sickness. Ataxia indicates cerebellar dysfunction due to cerebral edema and confirms the progression to this life-threatening condition, which requires immediate descent.

E) INCORRECT:

While papilledema may occur in severe cases of increased intracranial pressure, it is not practical for confirming high-altitude cerebral edema, as the test is unreliable and not readily available in the emergency setting.

questions.text: A 35-year-old presents with acute confusion and right arm weakness that developed shortly after completing a recreational dive to 3 meters' depth. A diving partner states the ascent appeared normal. Vital signs are BP, 125/80; P, 96; R, 18; oxygen saturation, 97% on room air. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Decompression sickness type II typically develops hours after diving rather than shortly after surfacing and usually occurs following deeper or longer dives with inadequate decompression time. The rapid onset of symptoms in this patient and shallow depth of the dive make this diagnosis less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitrogen narcosis occurs during diving at depths of 30 meters or greater due to increased partial pressure of nitrogen. Symptoms resolve rapidly after ascending to shallower depths.

C) INCORRECT:

Ear barotrauma typically manifests with vertigo, hearing loss, and ataxia rather than with focal weakness and confusion.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Arterial gas embolism manifests with focal neurological deficits and altered mental status. It can occur after brief and shallow dives, typically within 10 minutes of surfacing.

E) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary barotrauma with pneumothorax typically manifests with chest pain, dyspnea, and respiratory distress rather than with isolated neurological symptoms.
